org.sdsu.intelligrid.graphics

Class Sprite

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.sdsu.intelligrid.graphics.Sprite
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Drawable
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    ClickableSprite

    public class Sprite
extends java.lang.Object
implements Drawable
    A simple drawable object designed to render a single static sprite.

    • Constructor Detail

      • Sprite

        public Sprite(Vector2f location,
      float rotation,
      Vector2f scale,
      Color color,
      int resource)
        A simple drawable object designed to render a single static sprite.
        Parameters:
        location - the location of the sprite, in OpenGL coordinates ( [0.0,0.0] is the default position)
        rotation - the rotation of the sprite, in radians (0.0 means it is facing in the default direction)
        scale - the scale of the sprite ([1.0,1.0] is the default scale)
        color - the color factor of the sprite
        resource - the resource ID that the sprite should display (make sure it has been already loaded with MainRenderer#loadTextures(resources))

    • Method Detail

      • getLocation

        public Vector2f getLocation()
        Description copied from interface: Drawable
        Gets the drawable object's scene location. [0,0] is the center; on our device, in landscape mode, [-1.6,-1.0] is the bottom left corner and [1.6,1.0] is the top right corner. These values can change on other aspect ratios, so you should make it a habit of using MainRenderer.getLeftEdge() and the other similar functions to get the screen dimensions.
        Specified by:
        getLocation in interface Drawable
        Returns:
        the drawable object's current location

      • setLocation

        public void setLocation(Vector2f location)
        Sets the drawable object's scene location. [0,0] is the center; on our device, in landscape mode, [-1.6,-1.0] is the bottom left corner and [1.6,1.0] is the top right corner. These values can change on other aspect ratios, so you should make it a habit of using MainRenderer.getLeftEdge() and the other similar functions to get the screen dimensions.
        Parameters:
        loc - the desired location for the drawable object

      • getRotation

        public float getRotation()
        Gets the sprite's rotation, in radians. 0.0 is the default rotation.
        Returns:
        the sprite's current rotation, in radians

      • setRotation

        public void setRotation(float rotation)
        Sets the sprite's rotation, in radians.
        Parameters:
        scale - the desired rotation for the sprite, in radians

      • getScale

        public Vector2f getScale()
        Gets the sprite's scaling factor. [1.0,1.0] is the default scale.

        See setAbsoluteScale() and setRelativeScale().

        Returns:
        the sprite's current scaling factor

      • setScale

        public void setScale(Vector2f scale)
        Sets the sprite's scaling factor.

        See setAbsoluteScale() and setRelativeScale().

        Parameters:
        scale - the desired scaling factor for the sprite

      • getResource

        the resource ID that the sprite is using

      • getWidth

        public int getWidth()
        Gets the sprite image's actual width, in texels.

        the actual width, in texels, of the sprite image

      • getHeight

        public int getHeight()
        Gets the sprite image's actual height, in texels.
        Returns:
        the actual height, in texels, of the sprite image

      • setResource

        public void setResource(int resource)
        Sets the sprite's resource ID. Make sure it has been already loaded with MainRenderer#loadTextures(resources).
        Parameters:
        resource - the resource ID that the sprite should display

      • setAbsoluteScale

        public void setAbsoluteScale()
        Sets the scaling mode to absolute. This means that the sprite's size will remain consistent, in pixels, regardless of the screen size. For example, a 1280x800 image will appear to fill a quarter of the screen on a 2560x1600 display, at [1.0,1.0] scaling.

        This is the default scaling mode for sprites.

      • setRelativeScale

        public void setRelativeScale()
        Sets the scaling mode to relative. This means that the sprite's size will scale to the screen. For example, a 512x512 image will stretch to fill the whole vertical area of the screen on a 2560x1600 display, at [1.0,1.0] scaling.

      • advance

        public void advance(float amount)
        Description copied from interface: Drawable
        This is the primary step driver for the object. Call all time-based functions from here.
        Specified by:
        advance in interface Drawable
        Parameters:
        amount - the amount of time that has passed since the previous frame, in seconds

      • draw

        public void draw(float amount,
        float[] viewMatrix,
        float[] projectionMatrix)
        Description copied from interface: Drawable
        This is the drawing hook for the drawable object. Render the object here.
        Specified by:
        draw in interface Drawable
        Parameters:
        amount - the amount of time that has passed since the previous frame, in seconds
        viewMatrix - the current view matrix used in rendering
        projectionMatrix - the current projection matrix used in rendering
